First of all, I absolutely love this question because it gets to the reasoning behind why I chose to pursue mathematics! (Other than the fact that it is the laziest profession and thus suits my personality so well, of course.) Simply put, mathematics is so beautiful because it helps to take complicated processes that naturally occur in the world around us and represent them utilizing logic to make predictions. Let’s look at a fairly common example that almost everyone deals with at some point in their life. Money! Say you really want that new phone. It’s beautiful, excellent screen space with matching pixel ratio, superb battery life, latest processor, and the camera is finally advanced enough to take selfies worthy of your beauty. But it’s $1000, and you’ve only got $150 to spare at the moment. Woe always me! What’s a person to do?!? Math to the rescue! Being the resourceful little guy or gal you are, you have a job making $15/hr. That means we can make a function. Without diving into details, you can see a linear relationship here. Your rate of change is 15, and you began with 150. Let’s look at a graph to see when you’ll hit that $1000 mark.  Tada! You can see that at 56 hours you still won’t have quite enough, but after 57 hours, you’ll have enough to get that phone! This was a fairly simple real-world example of the applications of just a linear equation or two. We could have used inequalities to model the situation better as any amount over $1000 would do. You wouldn’t complain about having some extra after such a large purchase would you? Math is all about discovering methods to help model such situations. Trigonometry, Statistics, Calculus, and even more abstract classes all focus on different aspects of life to make predictions based on an observable pattern. Much more complicated processes that require more variables may have tolerances, or error ranges, that must also be calculated to help others see the likelihood of future occurrences. Depending on the area that you are interested in, you specialize in order to focus on the models unique to that study so you have multiple tools ready. As mentioned in another answer, mathematicians in any field do not “create” the way that things work. No one could make 2 + 2 = 4. Instead, someone recognized that having 2 quantities of anything and combining them with 2 more quantities resulted in 4 quantities. On the most basic level, we have something called groups and rings that rely on some kind of system followed by one or two operations. For example, our number system follows a ring utilizing the real numbers and the operations addition and multiplication. What about subtraction and division, you ask? We cover those with something called inverses. Subtraction is the same as adding a negative. For example, 5–3 is the same as 5+-3. Similarly, we never need to divide when we can just as easily multiply by a fraction. (Dividing by two is the same as taking half of a number.) And even at this advanced level, no mathematician created these ideas. Instead, they discovered patterns and proved mathematically that we can rely on those patterns and specific methods to solve other problems. Math allows us to create more advanced technology every day that make discoveries in medicine, architecture, and even space travel possible. Modeling these areas allows for their respective scientists to plan for the future by learning from the past to ensure the present is always moving forward.

It depends on what you mean by pattern. PATTERN | definition in the Cambridge English Dictionary a particular way in which something is done or organized, or in which something happens The first and primary definition in this dictionary is what comes to my mind, when I say “Mathematics is the language of pattern.”[1] Every mathematical discipline is built on definitions, axioms, synbols, and inferencing rules. These form the pattern for which a mathematician may have one or more conceptual models. Sometimes, special cases match observations of the real world; mathematics provides more general patterns that are not limitted by real world measurements.  Because mathematics describes all patterns, any pattern observed[2] or conceived can be communicated by mathematics. Since mathematics is abstract, the only topic which mathematics conveys is that of pattern! Footnotes[1] Math-The language of patterns - Cuemath[2] Everything in our life has only mathematical patterns.

My personal experience: abstraction. Abstraction means to take a practical situation, and ignore all aspects that “don’t really matter”. Whether counting cars, people, hours or ideas, it does not matter, it’s all counting. It turns out, many practical problems, when abstractified, boil down to the same. So, you only need to solve the abstract problem once, and that can give you the solution to a huge number of practical problems. Mathematics is a good language for such abstract problems. Many abstract problems can be reduced to elementary mathematical concepts such as sets, relations, functions, vector spaces, graphs, integrals, differentials, random variables,… Sadly, it’s not easy to learn how to abstractify a general practical problem. In fact, it’s even harder than the mathematics itself.
